tools.name: ask
tools.description: Ask a natural language question about the knowledge graph. Returns a synthesized answer backed by cited graph facts — not hallucination, real nodes with timestamps.

question.description: Plain English question, e.g. 'What do I know about Project Atlas?'

tools.name: remember
tools.description: Store a fact as a subject-predicate-object triple. Use for any relationship, preference, decision, or event worth keeping across sessions.

subject.description: The entity this fact is about, e.g. 'Alice'

object.description: The related entity or value, e.g. 'Orbit Labs'

tools.name: recall
tools.description: Get everything known about an entity — all incoming and outgoing relationships.

tools.name: search
tools.description: Search for entities in the graph by name (partial match). Use before recall() if unsure of exact name.

tools.name: timeline
tools.description: Get recent facts in reverse chronological order. Call at session start to see recent activity.

tools.name: graph_stats
tools.description: Get entity count, relationship count, and type breakdown for the graph.

tools.name: agent_context
tools.description: Get a complete natural-language context block summarizing the graph. Inject into system prompt at session start.

tools.name: subgraph
tools.description: Get a subgraph (nodes + edges) around an entity, up to N hops out. Use for visualization or deep relationship traversal.

tools.name: forget
tools.description: Delete a specific fact (subject-predicate-object triple). Removes the relationship, leaves entities intact. Use to correct wrong or outdated facts.

tools.name: forget_entity
tools.description: Delete an entity AND all its relationships. Use with care — permanently removes the node and every edge connected to it.

usage_tips: ask() is the most powerful tool — natural language in, cited graph facts out. Try it first.
Call agent_context() at session start to bootstrap memory.
Use remember_many (batch facts) instead of looping remember() for efficiency.
search() before recall() if you are not sure of the exact entity name.
Store facts with specific predicates — 'works_at' is better than 'related_to'.
Add context field for time-sensitive facts: 'As of March 2026'.
Entity labels are inferred from predicates — 'works_at' marks subject as Person, object as Organization.
Use forget() to correct wrong facts — it removes the relationship but keeps both entities.
Use forget_entity() to nuke a bad entity entirely — removes node AND all its edges.
